importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The decision to delay the Net Zero Framework adoption was made on this date, following President Trump's public threat to impose sanctions, marking a pivotal moment in global shipping emissions policy.
The Net Zero Framework was previously approved by the IMO in April 2025, setting a foundation for future global action on maritime emissions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The framework was delayed until late 2025, creating a new timeline for global shipping emissions reductions and climate mitigation efforts in maritime transport.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed approval of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months, despite its prior approval in April 2025.
U.S. President Donald Trump threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries supporting the framework, influencing the voting outcome.
The NZF would have introduced a global carbon tax of $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emitted by shipping vessels, with rewards for emission reductions.
The framework aims to cut shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050.
Countries such as China, the EU, Britain, and Brazil supported the initiative, while Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed it.
Argentina and Singapore, previously supportive, voted to delay the formal adoption.
The International Chamber of Shipping and Vanuatu’s climate minister criticized the delay as undermining climate action and industry investment clarity.
Climate change is already affecting shipping through altered ocean currents and more frequent storms, increasing urgency for emissions reductions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed the formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF)—a plan to reduce shipping emissions by implementing a global carbon tax of $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent—by at least 12 months, following threats from U.S. President Donald Trump to impose sanctions on countries supporting the measure. Despite earlier approval in April, the vote in London was influenced by political pressure, with key nations like China, the EU, and Britain maintaining support, while Russia, Saudi Arabia, Argentina, and Singapore shifted or voted to postpone. Industry leaders and climate advocates, including the International Chamber of Shipping and Vanuatu’s minister, criticized the delay as undermining climate goals and investment clarity. The NZF, aimed at cutting shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminating them by 2050, remains a critical step in addressing climate change impacts on shipping, including altered ocean currents and storm frequency.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
